It involved working out a syllabus for a course and a detailed plan. They also asked for a resumé and three references.  They told me they would get back to tell me about the outcome but they never did.  When I wrote to them asking for feedback they took their time to reply and then just said I had not been selected for another interview. I got the impression they already had a candidate in place and just wasted people's time. This is an organization that has no respect or empathy for applicants.

title: Intern, Program Assistant, Program Officer I Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions:
Successfully interviewed for 3 positions: Intern, Program Assistant, then Program Officer. The latter were both from an internal perspective.

I interviewed for a summer internship (paid). Began with a call with HR outlining the company, department, and position with expected pay. Then moved on to the skype interview (I was out of the state) with 2 managers and 3 analysts.

The Program Assistant and Program Officer positions interview processes were similar with a call with HR and then an in-person interview.

For the intern and Program Assistant positions I knew someone in the department. This helps a lot at FHI and in DC in general, it gets your resume to the top and someone to vouch for you.
Interview Questions:
Internship Q: On a scale from 1-10, 10 being high, how are your excel skills?
PA Q: Describe your prioritization process for when you have a lot of competing tasks on your plate?
PO Q: Question about my relationships with procurement and travel teams, and my familiarity with internal procurement processes.

title: Senior Finance Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at FHI 360
Interview Descriptions:
HR from Thailand office setup the initial interview schedule with the hiring manager in the local office.   It was a short call and she did not ask too many details about my qualifications and job experience. Hiring manager asked why I only stayed more than a year in the last company I worked for when I stayed in that company for more than 6 years holding 2 different positions. Hiring manager went straight in asking my expected salary. 

Hiring manager said that their budget is below my latest salary and asked me how much lower am I willing to reduce my salary.  Further said that if at that point I am not flexible in getting a lower pay, then she won't be able to include me in their short-listed candidate for the next round of interview. I was given until the following morning to decide if I am willing to accept a lower pay. I consented and was included in the 2nd round of interview with the Finance Manager of Thailand office.  

The 2nd interview went fine and  we discussed in details my job experience. At the end of the call, I was informed that the hiring manager will be the one to decide and inform me within 1 to 2 weeks about the result. I was interviewed March 23 and I sent a follow up email to the HR person in Thailand on April 9. I received a response after almost 3 weeks - April 27.
Interview Questions:
1. How much is your expected salary?
2. Tell us about your professional experience related to the job.

title: Program Officer Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process was multi-staged, with a phone screen, one-on-one phone call, received a data assignment, then had a presentation in person. This not unusual for jobs requiring a data analysis skill set. What IS unusual is getting all the way to the presentation stage and not receiving a single word of feedback. I never received noticed regarding the timeline for their decision making or the fact that I didn't get the job. It's incredibly rude of a potential employer to zap approximately 8-10 hours of your time over several interviews and an assignment yet not have the courtesy to simply send a "we regret to inform you" email. I dodged a bullet.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC) in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: I applied online in mid-April. An HR staff member in North Carolina emailed about a week later and set up a phone interview for a few days later. We had a great conversation. I was then invited for an in-person interview in DC. Another HR person (also in North Carolina) sent me an email with very detailed instructions and directions to get to the office. However, I did not have any information about the woman who actually interviewed me in the office. The interview was fine, neither amazing nor terrible. After making it all the way there to show up in person (at a very specific time that they needed, so I had to rush from another commitment in a private cab), I just never heard back though. No email from the interviewer or either of the two HR people who emailed me first. I sent two follow-up emails to both of them in the week or so to follow, and never got a response. They never bothered to send a rejection. That was very disappointing.

title: Program Officer I Linkages Interview

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC) in Sept 2015

I was approved for the next round of interviewing, which was on-site and with three employees working in the same business unit and having different roles in the projects with which I would be assisting. One person tended to lead the interview, asking most of the questions, with the other two asking more task-specific questions.
Interview Questions: Was there ever a time you could not deliver or perform on a request by a project partner, and what did you do to resolve the issue?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Durham, NC) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions:
After a phone interview/screening, which was very laid back and casual, I was scheduled for the in-person interview. The in-person interview process itself was long. The entire in-person process lasted about 3hours. It wasn't difficult. It was just long. I was exhausted when I left the building. I applied for the position online, and it took less than a week to get a call. They really needed the position filled, and about 4 or 5 others interviewed for it too, which I discovered later. 

I interviewed with the director of the department, three research associates, and a senior research associate/project coordinator in two separate one-on-one interviews, and then a three-person panel interview. Afterwards, I took a written assessment test on MS Office how-to's. The test also had situational questions.
Interview Questions: Describe the process step-by-step: How would you go about making and securing a travel itinerary (flights, ground transportation, hotel reservations, etc.) for a twenty-person international team to meet in Houston, TX at XYZ Hotel's conference room?

title: Senior Technical Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume via their website and was contacted by HR the next day to set up a screening interview. The screening interview was with HR and took about 15 minutes. I was also queried about my salary expectations as they didn't want to continue if my expectations were beyond what they were willing to pay. I benchmarked the position on Glassdoor, so my salary expectation fit their range. On to the next round. This was a Skype interview with a director and one other I would be working with in this position. It lasted about 45 minutes. I let them know I would be in the area and available for a face-to-face follow up. I did have a follow up at their office with the director again and two others from the funding agency. At the end of the interview, I was told that there would be decision in the next couple weeks. It has been over 1.5 months and I have not been contacted.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your experience with strategic planning?

I won't look for jobs at this company again.

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by an FHI 360 employee for the Program Officer position after they saw the job posting circulate.  I submitted my application and credentials online and the very next morning received a call from a recruiter for the position which served as a preliminary phone interview.  The recruiter then asked if I could come in the very next morning for a 1:1 interview.  I interviewed with the person who's position I was applying for (they were being promoted).  This interview was basic - it discussed my work experience, interests, academic background, etc.  I was asked to complete a scenario test that would be emailed to me and due the next morning.  Immediately after the interview I was asked to return for an interview the next day with the hiring managers.  The interview with the hiring managers -  one who would be my supervisor and the other with whom I would be working closely, was very thorough.  It built on the basic interview I had the previous day and went further into detail about the position's demands, responsibilities and expectations.  I answered questions that focused in-depth on relevant work experience and as well as work-ethic/personality questions.  The hiring managers were direct, open to questions, and personable.  Immediately after, I was asked for three references and three business days later I received an offer from my recruiter via phone call.  I countered the salary offer.  It took two weeks to receive a response to which my counter was rejected.  I accepted the offer and my first day was two weeks later.
Interview Questions: What I knew about education theory.

title: Business Development Consultant Interview

Never mind the fact that they had stated they had had trouble making contact with my references (which they never did call or reach out to them...I checked back with them) and despite the fact that they led me on a merry chase that ended up nowhere....

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at FHI 360 (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions:
Was contacted by HR and had an initial "screening" interview that lasted about 15 minutes. Then I had a second phone interview that lasted about half hour with a would-be supervisor, who was actually really great. Next had an in-person interview (about an hour), which required traveling to DC. The interview did not go as well as I would have wanted. However, the interviewer still instructed me to provide two writing samples even though she already knew she was not interested in me. I emailed the samples as soon as possible. I also wrote thank you emails after phone interviews and even hand wrote and mailed a thank you note after the in-person interview. Their communication with me stopped after the in-person interview. I thought this was very rude considering they were aware that I took a very taxing trip to DC (on my own buck) to meet with them. I even followed up about a week and half after I submitted my writing samples.

I am sure this organization is doing great work and that everyone is perfectly nice (including HR)  but I am not impressed by an organization that cannot take the time and consideration to reject a candidate who went through 3 interviews, sent both email and written thank you notes, and took the time to follow up with you. Had I gone through the first interview and not heard back, I would not even think about it too much, but three interviews at least deserves a one line rejection email.  To conclude, although things did not work out with this organization, I know I showed a high level of professionalism throughout the interview process, but I feel the company fell short in their level of professionalism towards me.
Interview Questions: How have you shown initiative at your previous work?; also my resume includes some managerial work (in an education nonprofit) and previous experience teaching. This somehow confused the interviewer who was not sure how these related and couldn't understand what I was actually interested in (i.e managerial or technical work). I was questioned about that. Although I answered the question clearly, the way she asked the question did throw me off internally.
